Kedarnath.origin_story: According to legend, after the Kurukshetra war, the Pandavas sought Lord Shiva for forgiveness. Shiva disguised himself as a bull and dove into the ground; his hump appeared in Kedarnath, where the temple was built.
Kedarnath.significance: One of the twelve Jyotirlingas and an important Char Dham site. It represents the cosmic form of Shiva as the Lord of Time and Liberation.
Kedarnath.rituals_festivals: Rudrabhishek, Shravan month pujas, and Badri-Kedar Utsav.
Kedarnath.best_time_to_visit: May to June, and September to early October.
Kedarnath.spiritual_meaning: Represents surrender, dissolution of ego, and spiritual awakening.

Badrinath.origin_story: Adi Shankaracharya rediscovered the idol of Lord Vishnu in the Alaknanda River and established it as Badrinarayan.
Badrinath.significance: One of the holiest Vaishnavite shrines and part of the Char Dham. Symbolizes Moksha and protection.
Badrinath.rituals_festivals: Badri-Kedar Festival, Mata Murti Ka Mela.
Badrinath.best_time_to_visit: May to June and September to October.
Badrinath.spiritual_meaning: Symbol of compassion, devotion, and purity.

Jagannath Puri.origin_story: The temple was built by King Anantavarman Chodaganga Deva. Lord Jagannath is believed to manifest here with his siblings Balabhadra and Subhadra.
Jagannath Puri.significance: One of the four primary Char Dham pilgrimage sites.
Jagannath Puri.spiritual_meaning: Represents equality, unity, and divine love.

Dwarkadhish.origin_story: Dwarka is believed to be the kingdom of Lord Krishna, sunk into the sea after his departure.
Dwarkadhish.significance: One of the four Char Dhams; place where Krishna ruled.

Somnath.origin_story: First among the 12 Jyotirlingas; believed to be created by the Moon God and later rebuilt many times after destruction.
Somnath.spiritual_meaning: Represents immortality and the eternal nature of the soul.

Mahakaleshwar.origin_story: Shiva manifested as Mahakal to protect the devotees of Ujjain from a demon.
Mahakaleshwar.significance: Only Jyotirlinga facing south, representing Shiva as the Lord of Time.

Rameshwaram.origin_story: Built by Lord Rama after returning from Lanka; he installed a Shiva lingam to seek forgiveness for killing Ravana.
Rameshwaram.significance: One of the Char Dhams; highly sacred for both Shaivites and Vaishnavites.
Rameshwaram.spiritual_meaning: Symbol of duty, devotion, and humility.

Tirupati Balaji.origin_story: Lord Vishnu manifested as Venkateshwara to save humanity during Kaliyuga.
Tirupati Balaji.significance: One of the richest and most visited temples in the world.

Kashi Vishwanath.origin_story: The temple marks the cosmic center of Shiva’s power, rebuilt many times in history.

Vaishno Devi.origin_story: Mata Vaishno Devi meditated in these caves while escaping Bhairav Nath.
Vaishno Devi.significance: One of India's most revered Shakti Peethas.
Vaishno Devi.spiritual_meaning: Symbol of Shakti, protection, and divine motherhood.
